previewPlan.name: SYSTM Multisport Transition Up; short course
previewPlan.description: Transition Up is for triathletes coming off a period of little or no activity who are ready to get back into structured indoor training. Sport specific sessions (swim, bike, run) progress from lower intensity in the early part of the plan to higher intensity over the course of six weeks, with a significant focus on pedaling efficiency on the bike and neuromuscular development for the swim and run. Cross-training sessions follow a progression from gentle mobility and stability sessions into functional strength work designed to improve pedaling efficiency, body mechanics and durability to help triathletes stay comfortable during longer training sessions later in the season.
previewPlan.planDescription: Get ready for your best indoor season yet with the Multisport Transition Up plan

prospects.name: Strides & Drills
prospects.description:
This is a technique-focused session designed to develop your agility, stability, range of motion, and foot speed. There is no focus on heart rate zones so you may choose to leave your monitor at home for these sessions. Between sets of each drill, you should jog/walk easily to fully recover between the efforts. While these efforts shouldn’t be too taxing on you, the key is perfect form, so you want to be hitting each one rested enough that you can maintain great form for the duration. You should take a bit of extra rest between techniques, again to ensure you are rested and can nail the form. Before starting the workout, familiarize yourself with the format for high knees, butt kicks, skipping, carioca and strides. Find a flat track, field, or 50-100m of open space to perform this workout (football and soccer fields are great for this).

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-up:**

Start off with 5-10 minutes of easy jogging/walking.

High Knees: 2-3 sets of 50m high knees.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Take short strides, bringing your knees up high enough that your upper legs are parallel to the ground. Focus on achieving high knees AND quick turnover, or performing as many reps as possible in a short distance.

**Butt Kicks:**

2-3 sets of 50m butt kicks.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- This should actually look similar to a high knee drill, but with the heels coming up to touch the bottom of your butt. Take short strides while using your hamstrings to lift your heels up beneath your butt. Your knees should come up in front of your body while pulling your heels up beneath your hips, rather than keeping your quads and knees below and in line with your hips.

**Skipping:**

3-4 sets of 50m skipping.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Focus on a high knee drive and swinging your arms at your sides like you would when running.

**Carioca:**

4 sets of 30m Carioca in each direction (8 total).

Rest for 20 seconds between direction changes (at your discretion).

- For this drill, you need to face sidewise to the direction you want to go. Start off moving to the right. Bring your left knee up and across your body and put your left foot in front of your right foot. Step your right foot to the right so it is parallel with your left leg again (at this point you should be positioned in the same direction and orientation that you were at the start. Next step your left leg behind your right leg, again so it lands on the right side of your right leg. Then bring your right leg back across your body, once again ending up in the starting position. Repeat this pattern for 25-30m.

**Strides:**

2-3 sets of 60m; Gradually build effort from RPE 3-8.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between. These are comprised of a steady acceleration over 60-80m up to 5k pace. The goal is to increase speed after each step, so you are reaching maximum speed at the end of the 60-80m stretch. You want to focus on keeping your shoulders, neck, and jaw relaxed while maintaining strong knee drive, straight and compact arm swing, planting the feet beneath the hips, and fast turnover.

​

High Knees + Butt Kicks:

Finish these drills with one set each of 50m high knees and butt kicks.

​

**Cool-down:**

Walk or jog for 5 minutes to cool down.

In case you need to brush up on your running [drills](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ)

prospects.name: Total Newbie Yoga
prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Technique A
prospects.description:
In case you need to brush up on your other [technique definitions or drills](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterSwimDrills).

For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

Good swimming technique is the key to efficient swimming. Today's session is a low intensity workout that challenges you with a series of drills designed to reinforce proper technique that will make you a more efficient, powerful and faster swimmer.

​

**Warm-Up**

200m stroke of your choice @ RPE 2 -- Z1

​

**Activation 1**

Number of Sets: 4

Interval Distance: 25m Drill of choice

The goal of a Drill set is not to swim at any given pace, but instead focus on proper form. Choose a drill or focus on one of these key points for each 25m interval:

- \*Body position- swim on horizontal plane
- \*Enter in front of shoulder- preventing cross over
- \*Breathe early- prevent wide stroke- elbow is always widest point
- \*Elbow is always the highest point of the stroke
- \*Back of hand always faces direction of travel
- \*Fingers to point at the bottom of pool
- \*Initiate your stroke from the hips

Recovery: 10 seconds rest

​

**Activation 2**

Number of Sets: 1

Interval Distance:

200m Pull @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2

- This set eliminates the use of your legs. It requires a buoy that you can swim with between your legs. The buoy will keep your body in the correct orientation. By removing your legs from the drill you will be required to only use your arms. This will help you focus on efficient form and making the most of each stroke!

Recovery: 20 seconds rest

​

**Main Effort**

The following should all be done at a moderate pace (RPE 2-4 -- Z1-Z2), with enough rest between that you can focus on proper form

Interval 1: 150m of One Arm Freestyle drill

- This is an old standby. Put your non-pulling arm out in front of your body and swim with only the opposite arm. Take some time to watch the arm that is pulling. Feel your elbow directly above your hand and that you are pulling right down the midline of your body. Split your body in half with your fingertips. Your emphasis should be on power and efficiency not on speed.
- See how few strokes you can take to get down the pool.
- Once you have it mastered, you can leave the non-pulling arm at your side.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 2: 200m of 3/4 Catch Up drill

- A variation to catch-up that takes us closer to the full stroke. Another way to describe this is almost catch-up. Take a stroke with the right hand, wait until this hand is almost all the way through recovery and then start your pull with the left. This creates a very rhythmic feel, almost like skating through the water. Take your pull and ride the glide from it. When you lose speed, take your next pull. Want a good example of this? Watch Olympic replays of the Aussies, particularly Ian Thorpe. He races like this drill. Efficiency is your goal.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 3: 200m of Elbow-Hip-Elbow drill

- A variation on side glide kick. The same goals apply balance, body roll, and head position during breathing. Start on either side with one arm extended out front, and the other at your side. With the fingers of the hand at your side, touch the elbow of your upper arm, then your hip, and then the elbow again. Now take your stroke or three strokes. Kick and glide and repeat.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 4: 150m of Fist Drill

- Swim freestyle with your hands in fists. This is going to force you to get your forearms involved in the stroke because they have more surface area than your hands. Keep your elbow high under the water. Your forearm, from elbow to fingertips should be perpendicular to the bottom of the pool. Again, watch Ian Thorpe. You will feel like you are slipping through the water which is normal, however, the more water you feel like you are pulling the more efficient you are getting.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 5: 200m of Zipper Drill

- This drill is done by pulling the fingers up the side of the body until they come into the armpit. The point of this is to keep a nice high elbow on recovery and to force the body to roll. Many use the Fingertip drag drill to accomplish this but we prefer this drill because the body roll essentially gives this drill a dual purpose.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Repeat until full swim time is completed

​

**Cool Down**

200m stroke of your choice @ RPE < 2 -- Z1

​

**Total Distance**

1600m

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Half Monty (Ramp Test)
prospects.description:
**Half Monty: The Easy One.**

​

We recommend this fitness test for:

- Newer riders
- Athletes with limited experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those who are mid-plan or who just want to get a sense of where their fitness is.

The _Half Monty_ 4DP fitness test is the most accurate and complete ramp test available. While it's not as comprehensive or as accurate as our main fitness test, _Full Frontal_, it's far more approachable and easier to pace for new riders. It also doesn't require any special preparation. You just need to feel relatively fresh.

​

Based on more than a year of research (and after dozens of lab tests and thousands of online tests) and using sophisticated analysis of power and heart rate data, _Half Monty_ is far more accurate and comprehensive than standard ramp tests.

​

It also tells you more about who you are as an athlete. _Half Monty_ provides you with your FTP, Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and Cycling Threshold Heart Rate (cTHR), all of which we use to personalize your workout targets.

​

If you're still using the 4DP estimates when you set up your account, _Half Monty_ will also refine your AC and NM estimates (but will not do so if you've done _Full Frontal_ or manually adjusted your estimates). If you want fully accurate AC and NM, as well as your Rider Type, Strengths, Weaknesses, and training plans adjusted to those Strengths and Weaknesses, you'll need to expose yourself to the _Full Frontal_ 4DP fitness test.

​

Ready to climb the ramp? You'll need the following before you start:

- A heart rate monitor if you want the most accurate results. Don't have one? Order one [HERE](https://wahoofitness.com/devices)
- Some kind of power device connected (trainer, power meter, virtual power, etc.)
- Be ready to pay close attention to the instructions in the workout
- Be sure your profile is complete and up-to-date (Profile > About You). Accurate information helps us make our calculations

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: Mobilize and Activate
prospects.description: Get out of your habitual movement patterns and get ready to take on the day with this activation session. You'll flow through a series of standing yoga poses to simultaneously challenge your strength, flexibility, and range of motion, leaving you feeling energized.

prospects.name: Breathing More Deeply
prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Aerobic with Pickups
prospects.description:
For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2-4 -- 145-120% of RTP -- HR 70-87% (Z1-Z2)

​

**Main Effort:**

Number of Sets: 1

Interval Repeats Per set: 5

Interval Effort: 30 second acceleration from RPE 4-8 -- 120% of RTP up to 90% of RTP (Z2-Z4)

Recovery: 4 minutes @ RPE 2-4 -- 145-120% of RTP -- HR 70-87% (Z2)

​

**Extra Volume:**

NA

​

**Cool Down:**

End your workout with 5 minutes of easy jogging (Z1)

prospects.name: Hip and Pelvis Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we strengthen the hips through their full range of motion and stabilize the pelvis to improve balance and reduce your risk of knee, IT band, and lower back injury. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Full Body 03
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

In this session, we begin adding variations to the foundational moves you’ve mastered so far (you’ve mastered them, right?). This will keep challenging you, as will the increases in duration of a few sets -- such as the squats -- so you can complete a few more reps.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Forward Lunge
- Lateral Lunge with Extended Hands
- Hip Hinge
- Single-Leg Squat with Opposite Reach
- Squat with Wide Stance
- Hip Bridge
- Frog Crunch
- Push-Up On Knees
- Back Extension with Reps
- Quadruped with Arm Raise
- Plank
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Side Plank
- Side Plank with Leg Raise
- Side Plank with Pulsing Hand

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: 3 x (8 x 25m)
prospects.description:
For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

**Warm Up**

Number of Sets: 1

Number of Repeats: 6 x 100m @ RPE 3-4-- Z2, Focusing on distance per stroke

20 sec rest

​

**Activation**

Number of sets: 1

Number of Repeats: 8

Interval: 50m @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2 as 25m Side-Glide-Kick drill + 25m swim

Recovery: 20 sec rest

- Push off the wall on your side and kick for eight kicks. Keep your ear on your arm and your body straight. Make sure your knees are passing one another when you kick. Eight strokes and then take a good pull with the arm up top. Use this pull to roll you to the other side and repeat the cycle. For variation do this drill with three strokes in between. I.e. on right side with right arm up and left arm at your side. Take a pull with the right, left and right. End with your left arm up and your right arm at your side. This will help improve your body position in the water and if you keep your head on your arm when you are on your side it will help your head position when you breathe.

**Main Set**

Number of Sets: 3

Interval 1: 8 x 25m @ RPE 9 -- Z5

Recovery: 15 sec rest

Interval 2: (Between each set of 25's) 100m backstroke or breaststroke @ RPE 2 -- Z1

​

**Cool Down**

200m @ RPE 2 -- Z1, choice of strokes

​

**Total Distance**

1900m

prospects.name: Endurance Brick 15
prospects.description:
For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-Up**

Bike Session

​

**Main Effort:**

Interval Duration: 15 mins

Interval Effort: RPE 2-4 -- 145-120% of RTP --HR 70-87% (Z2)

Recovery: NA

Extra Volume:NA

​

**Cool Down**

NA (This is a steady Z2 run immediately after your bike session. Use this as an opportunity to practice your second transition!)

prospects.name: Tempo/FTP Progressive Build
prospects.description: This 32-minute long session is about increasing the intensity of your effort in a two steps forward, one step back approach. You can use this session to build your sustained endurance, or even use it as a long warm-up with relatively gradual increase in intensity to get ready for something even harder. Any way you ride this workout, you'll be building great endurance capacity!

prospects.name: Core Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the spine, ribs and pelvis; strengthen the deep abdominals, obliques and lower back; and activate the glutes to improve balance, help to prevent and alleviate lower back pain and enhance athletic performance. It's a great session to do in the morning or pre-workout.

prospects.name: Aerobic Swim 45
prospects.description:
This session can also be performed in open water if available. 

​

For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

This is a steady, low-intensity swim designed to keep your system ticking over without adding too much fatigue. Make it a priority to never go above Z2.

​

**Warm-Up**

100m stroke of your choice @ RPE 3 -- Z2

Recovery: 15 seconds rest

100m Kicking @ RPE 5 -- Z3

Recovery: 15 seconds rest

​

**Main Effort**

Steady swim @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2 for the duration of the workout as specified by your training plan.

Use pace clock to ensure lap times are remaining consistent

Count strokes every 5 laps to ensure consistency

Practice your sighting at least once every 100m

​

**Cool Down**

200m Pull @ RPE 2 -- Z1

​

**Total Distance**

2000m

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: # Getting Away With It (November Groundwork Challenge)
prospects.description:
This workout is part of the Wahoo X Monthly Challenge. Click [++here++](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/t/wahoo-november-challenge-groundwork/30430) to find out more.

​

Wouldn't it be great if you could leave work to go for a ride? Even for an hour? Well, now's your chance. _Getting Away With It_ gets you out of the office and onto the roads of the French Pyrenees with your guide Michael Cotty of The Col Collective.

​

This is a great session to add toward the end of a training block. The shorter duration, sub-threshold efforts are fantastic for getting some extra FTP building while you are in a fatigued state. Extra emphasis on cadence stresses your nervous system, making your body more efficient at higher and lower RPMs while improving your form. The Neuromuscular training you get from this session is fantastic, so while your power never exceeds threshold, your body will learn to bring more energy to the pedals at all intensities.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Aerobic Run 30
prospects.description:
For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

This is an easy, fun, and unstructured run designed to keep your system ticking over without adding too much fatigue. Make it a priority to never go above Z2, and a good way to do this is to go for a run with a friend and keep it at a conversational pace (or talk to yourself!).

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see this article.

​

**Warm-Up**

NA

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: NA

Interval Duration: 30 minutes

Interval Effort: RPE 2-4 -- 145-120% of RTP --HR 70-87% (Z2)

Recovery: NA

​

**Cool Down**

NA

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Technique C
prospects.description:
In case you need to brush up on your swimming [technique definitions or drills](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterSwimDrills).

For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

Good swimming technique is the key to efficient swimming. Today's session is a low intensity workout that challenges you with a series of drills designed to reinforce proper technique that will make you a more efficient, powerful and faster swimmer.

​

**Warm-Up**

200m stroke of your choice @ RPE 2 -- Z1

​

**Activation 1**

Number of Sets: 4

Interval Distance: 25m Drill of your choice

The goal of a Drill set is not to swim at any given pace, but instead focus on proper form. Choose a drill or focus on one of these key points for each 25m interval:

- \*Body position- swim on horizontal plane
- \*Enter in front of shoulder- preventing cross over
- \*Breathe early- prevent wide stroke- elbow is always widest point
- \*Elbow is always the highest point of the stroke
- \*Back of hand always faces direction of travel
- \*Fingers to point at the bottom of pool
- \*Initiate your stroke from the hips

Recovery: 10-sec rest

​

**Activation 2**

Number of Sets: 1

Interval Distance: 100m kick @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2

- This drill requires you to only use your legs for propulsion. Face the sky with your arms extended above your head, biceps squeezing your ears. Kick from the hips with straight legs, toes just breaking the surface of the water. When you see the flags above your head, flip onto your belly so you don't hit the wall. Make note if there are no flags at your pool before doing this drill so you can look for another sign that the wall is near.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

​

**Activation 3**

Number of Sets: 1

Interval Distance: 100m Pull @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2

- This set eliminates the use of your legs to focus on your catch and pull. Squeeze a pull buoy between your legs to keep your hips afloat and body in the correct orientation.
- While the back of the hand always faces the direction of travel and the elbow remains the highest point of the stroke, your leading hand spears the water and the Catch phase is initiated by obtaining a grasp on the water while reaching forward. This first phase is not about producing power, rather, it sets you up for the Pull and Push Phases. Imagine pulling yourself over a barrel. Hold as much water as possible while pulling, then pushing the water back to your thigh keeping the hand on the inside on the elbow. Your stroke should accelerate as you progress through the Pull and Push Phases. There is a subtle S formation that occurs during the phases, starting with the Pull Phase just above the shoulder and continuing through the Push Phase until your hand exits the water to begin the recovery phase. Always imagine a line dividing your body lengthwise, with your left arm staying on the left side and your right arm staying on the right side. Crossover will result in additional drag and unwanted sway in the lower body.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

​

**Main Set**

Complete at least six of the drills that you struggle the most with. Aim for 150-200m of each one. The only way to get better is to work on your weaknesses! So be honest with yourself and pick the drills you have the hardest time with.

​

**Cool Down**

200m stroke of your choice @ RPE < 2 -- Z1

​

**Total Distance**

2000m

prospects.name: Made This
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2024): In professional bike racing, we don't often see the whole picture. We only see the starts and the finishes, the breakaways and crashes, the near misses and podiums. Made This presented by Wahoo + MAAP is a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with women's pro cycling team Lifeplus - Wahoo:

1. **Sisterhood: **Dedication, challenges, commitment, belief, family and sisterhood are all components of what it takes to be a professional racing team. In the first of a series of behind-the-scenes, unfiltered front-row access with team Lifeplus-Wahoo, MADE THIS is a collection of short films from MAAP Pro Team Racing that reveals what it takes to make a champion a champion.
2. **Prepared for anything: **The excitement of Holy Week at the Tour de Flanders is upon us, and Team Lifeplus-Wahoo is gearing up for a challenging ride. With 163km to conquer, featuring 12 climbs and seven cobbled stretches, not to mention seven slippery flat stone sections—all under a deluge of rain—anything could happen.
3. **Passion on the cobbles: **Join us as we dive deep into the chaotic and exhilarating world of the Paris-Roubaix, one of cycling's most grueling races. Amidst the cobblestones and mud, Team Lifeplus-Wahoo faces the ultimate test of endurance and skill. With a new lineup and high stakes, the team navigates the unpredictable nature of this legendary race, where luck can play a huge role and every second counts.
4. **Home sweet home: **After a fallow year for the tour, the team are eager to push for results in front of an expectant crowd. But instead of the warm welcome on familiar roads, disaster strikes the first morning of the race. As national news of the unfortunate event breaks, the team are left wondering if they'll be able to compete or if this becomes a home visit to forget. What follows is a true act of human kindness and a gesture that symbolises the unifying bond of the women's pro peloton.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Balance and Agility
prospects.description: Maintaining effective cycling form when you're under pressure requires substantial balance, coordination, agility, and core strength. This series will develop those capabilities so you can put down the power when it really matters.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: The Laps Tasmania
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2019): Following Dustin Hollick and Rhian Slapp, two ordinary fathers with the survival skills of well-trained house pets, on a two-week journey around Tasmania with not much more than the clothes on their backs. No cash, no car, and no technology on an island at the bottom of the world.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Aerobic Run 30
prospects.description:
For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

This is an easy, fun, and unstructured run designed to keep your system ticking over without adding too much fatigue. Make it a priority to never go above Z2, and a good way to do this is to go for a run with a friend and keep it at a conversational pace (or talk to yourself!).

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see this article.

​

**Warm-Up**

NA

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: NA

Interval Duration: 30 minutes

Interval Effort: RPE 2-4 -- 145-120% of RTP --HR 70-87% (Z2)

Recovery: NA

​

**Cool Down**

NA

prospects.name: Lower Back Release
prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Wind-Relieving
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Knees-To-Chest
- Reclining Hand-To-Big-Toe
- Dead Pigeon
- Happy Baby

prospects.name: Full Body 03
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

In this session, we begin adding variations to the foundational moves you’ve mastered so far (you’ve mastered them, right?). This will keep challenging you, as will the increases in duration of a few sets -- such as the squats -- so you can complete a few more reps.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Forward Lunge
- Lateral Lunge with Extended Hands
- Hip Hinge
- Single-Leg Squat with Opposite Reach
- Squat with Wide Stance
- Hip Bridge
- Frog Crunch
- Push-Up On Knees
- Back Extension with Reps
- Quadruped with Arm Raise
- Plank
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Side Plank
- Side Plank with Leg Raise
- Side Plank with Pulsing Hand

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: 2 x (16 x 25m)
prospects.description:
For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

**Warm Up**

Number of Sets: 1

Number of Repeats: 6 x 100m @ RPE 3-4-- Z2, Focusing on distance per stroke

20 sec rest

​

**Activation**

Number of sets: 1

Number of Repeats: 8

Interval: 50m @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2 as 25 m Side-Glide-Kick drill + 25m swim

- Push off the wall on your side and kick for eight kicks. Keep your ear on your arm and your body straight. Make sure your knees are passing one another when you kick. Eight strokes and then take a good pull with the arm up top. Use this pull to roll you to the other side and repeat the cycle. For variation do this drill with three strokes in between. I.e. on right side with right arm up and left arm at your side. Take a pull with the right, left and right. End with your left arm up and your right arm at your side. This will help improve your body position in the water and if you keep your head on your arm when you are on your side it will help your head position when you breathe. Recovery: 20 sec rest

**Main Set**

Number of Sets: 2

Interval 1: 16 x 25m @ RPE 9 -- Z5

Recovery: 10 sec rest

Interval 2: (Between sets 1 and 2) 100m backstroke or breaststroke @ RPE 2 -- Z1

​

**Cool Down**

200m @ RPE 2 -- Z1, choice of strokes

​

**Total Distance**

1700m

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Lake Chira
prospects.description:
Our first ever On Location gravel adventure and what a ride we have in store! This one may be short but it’ll have you hanging onto the edge of your saddle as we explore the Pilancones Natural Park, high up on a mountain ridge overlooking the Soria valley as we head towards Chira Lake. The goal of this ride will be to work on your good form with a slightly higher cadence than normal, keeping the legs supple and spinning. We’ll gently build the effort up a 3km climb to get the heart, legs and lungs working a little harder before descending to our final destination at Chira Lake. This workout is perfect for those days when you need an easier session or want to activate the body before going deeper.

​

This workout focusses on a progressive build through the duration of the climb helping with your pacing skills and sustained efforts.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8773915186)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Aerobic w/pickups Brick
prospects.description:

**Main Effort**

prospects.name: Swim Focus 1
prospects.description:
_The Swim Focus Sessions combine fundamental core and posterior chain exercises with additional attention on shoulder stability and upper body strength. We’ve also included essential lower body moves to build leg strength and full body coordination. Even though these workouts are designed for swimming, anyone looking for a full-body workout can get a boost from these sessions especially if you need a bit more upper body strength in your routine._

​

_Sessions 1-4 follow a gradual progression with increased set times and more demanding exercise combinations. Swim Focus -Travel is designed to go with you on the road, requiring almost no equipment at all. We recommend that you start with Swim Focus 1 and master all of the movements before advancing._

​

In **Swim Focus 1** we introduce you to foundational moves. Master them as you’ll see these exercises throughout the program. As you progress, we'll continue to add more difficult variations on these basics - so develop good habits now for quality execution down the road. Exercises include:

- Shoulder Rolls
- Hip Hinge
- Standing Knee lift
- Diagonal Straight Arm Raise
- External Shoulder Rotation w/band
- Fire Hydrant
- Low Plank with Lat Pull w/band
- Back Extension
- Narrow Pushup
- Streamline Lunge Front Alt.
- Swim Strokes w/Band
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- 45° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- 90° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Wide Pushup
- Kick on Side
- Oblique Leg Lifts
- Pushup w/ Rotation
- Low Plank w/ Toe Tap
- Frog Stretch
- Pigeon Stretch

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: The Holy Week
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): The Holy Week tells the story from the eve of the Tour of Flanders right through until the tense finale on the Roubaix velodrome. Through the eyes of the riders, team staff, and devoted roadside fans, we go behind the scenes to capture the essence of the cobbled classics, and the emotions of one of the most compelling campaigns of recent years.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts are low enough that they won't distract you from the story while being just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

This is an easy, fun, and unstructured run designed to keep your system ticking over without adding too much fatigue. Make it a priority to never go above Z2, and a good way to do this is to go for a run with a friend and keep it at a conversational pace (or talk to yourself!).

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see this article.

prospects.name: Chest & Shoulder Strength
prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Triceps Push-Ups
- Plank
- Child
- Downward Dog
- Puppy
- Chest Stretch
- Triceps Stretch
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Standing Starts
prospects.description:
_Standing Starts_ closely simulates a lifting session on the bike because it requires the engagement of your core, upper body, and lower body. It trains your ability to generate force through the pedals by ensuring you recruit ALL of your muscles to get those cranks turning. No matter your preferred discipline, these efforts are key to teaching your body to recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs.

​

All of the benefits in this session come from hitting these 20-second efforts as hard as you possibly can. To do that, you need full recovery between each sprint, and you need to respect that recovery. These efforts should see you start at super low RPMs with very high torque. As you start and increase the effort, your cadence will naturally increase. **Your goal is to get your cadence as high as possible by the end of each 20-second effort.** To maximize your muscle recruitment, you want to both push down and pull up on the pedals at the start. Proper core engagement is a must - your legs need a good strong backboard to push against.

​

We understand that not everyone's trainer has the necessary resistance or the required stability to perform this workout as described. If you can't safely stand up, then you can get much of the same benefit by doing these efforts seated. If your trainer can’t handle the rapid change in speed or does not have high enough resistance at a super low cadence, then you can start the efforts at a higher cadence and treat them as “normal” all-out sprints.

prospects.name: Full Body 05
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

In this routine, we’re going to throw in a few moves you haven’t seen yet to complete the foundational moves in the Full Body series. You’ll also find some new, subtle variations to the exercises you know well. While the differences seem small, the unique demands will speed up your adaptation phase.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- Hip Bridge
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Reverse Lunge with Hands Over Head
- Backward Lunge
- Lateral Lunge with Same Hand
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Hinge with Opposite Reach
- Single-Leg Squat with Hands Forward
- Goblet Squat
- Push-Up On Knees
- Back Extension
- Back Extension with Reps
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Alternate Arm Reach
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Side Plank with Hip Raise
- Side Plank with Hip Drop
- High Side Plank
- Half Twists

prospects.name: 20 x 50 (15 Polo, 35 DPS)
prospects.description:
For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

**Warm Up**

Number of Sets: 2

Interval: 100m starting @ RPE 2 -- Z1 and descending to RPE 5 -- Z3

Number of Repeats: 3

Recovery: 20 sec rest

​

**Activation**

Number of sets: 2

Interval: 150m @ RPE 5 -- Z3 as: 50m Kick, 50m Pull, 50m Swim

Recovery: 30s rest

​

**Main Set**

Number of Sets: 2

Interval 1: 50m as: 15m Polo Swim

35m Distance per Stroke drill

Number of repeats: 10

Recovery: 20 sec rest

- This is drill is great practice for sighting in open water events and amplifies the feel on the front end of the catch. Begin with your head out of the water focusing on reaching out to the front while keeping your elbows high with a strong, tight, fast kick. Complete this drill by executing 6 freestyle strokes with your head out of the water followed by 6 freestyle strokes with your head in the water.

Active Recovery: 50m @ RPE 2 -- Z1, choice of stroke

Interval 2: 100m @ RPE 9 -- Z5

Number of repeats: 3

Recovery: 15 sec rest

Active recovery: 100m @ RPE 2 -- Z1 choice of stroke

​

**Cool Down**

100-200m @ RPE 2 -- Z1, choice of strokes

​

**Total Distance**

2600m

prospects.name: Micro Intervals: Equal Work Rest 10/20/30/20/10
prospects.description: Over 42-minutes, this session throws 5 sets of micro intervals of equal duration efforts and recoveries to help boost your MAP. You might notice that the middle set of efforts is similar to The Model for good reason. This is a perfect go-to workout for a short MAP focussed micro-interval session to get your aerobic engine primed and boosted for longer efforts.

prospects.name: Mobilize Your Body
prospects.description:
In this video, we focus on mobilizing the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, ankles, and toes to enhance overall mobility throughout the body. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or evening to alleviate stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase mobility in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, and ankles.

prospects.name: Swim Focus 2
prospects.description:
_The Swim Focus Sessions combine fundamental core and posterior chain exercises with additional attention on shoulder stability and upper body strength. We’ve also included essential lower body moves to build leg strength and full body coordination. Even though these workouts are designed for swimming, anyone looking for a full-body workout can get a boost from these sessions especially if you need a bit more upper body strength in your routine._

​

_Sessions 1-4 follow a gradual progression with increased set times and more demanding exercise combinations. Swim Focus -Travel is designed to go with you on the road, requiring almost no equipment at all. We recommend that you start with Swim Focus 1 and master all of the movements before advancing._

​

In Swim Focus 2 we add variations to the foundational moves from Swim Focus 1 (you’ve mastered them, right?). The modifications will challenge you, as will the increased duration of a few sets -- such as the push ups -- so you can complete a few more reps. Exercises include:

prospects.name: G.O.A.T.
prospects.description:
This session is all about high-torque efforts, very similar to the efforts you would experience riding up the steep slopes of Mt Sufferlandria. While these efforts are short and the intensity isn’t too high, the low cadence targets combined with minimal recovery will leave some begging for the high-cadence sprints of _The Omnium_. High-torque efforts like these have two primary benefits: improved neuromuscular coordination and increased muscular endurance.

​

During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. High-cadence efforts in something like _Cadence Builds_ are great for teaching these groups to make that switch quickly. These low-cadence efforts are better for teaching ALL of the muscles in your legs to “switch on.” Done properly, you should be pulling with your hamstrings with one leg while the other leg is pushing down with all the force your glutes and quads can muster. If you feel like you are pushing yourself up out of the saddle during harder efforts (like seated sprints), your hamstrings are not being utilized since they should pull you back down into your saddle.

​

The second main benefit is improved muscular endurance. Even though the session is under 45 minutes, **you'll put a similar amount of muscular fatigue into your legs as a steady, multi-hour base ride.** You can almost view this session as hitting the leg press for 8 sets of 100 reps. And just like the weight room, proper form is absolutely key. That means:

- You should focus on pushing down AND pulling back up. You want your glutes and quads activated on the way down and your hamstring and hip flexors activated on the way up.
- To properly engage your hamstrings think about trying to pulling your heel up to your butt when your crank arm is going from 6 o’clock to 10 o’clock.
- Your knees should be tracking straight up and down, no collapsing in or out.
- Your core should be fully engaged to keep your hips steady in the saddle. This will be easier if you are both pushing and pulling during each pedal revolution.

This session is very similar to _Power Station_. Both help improve your muscular endurance and coordination; the biggest difference is the work to rest ratio between the two. While the intervals here are shorter than those in _Power Station_, the decreased recovery duration means fatigue will build faster, especially for those with a weakness in repeated efforts.

Modifying interval length and recovery duration can also be seen between sessions like _Revolver_ and _A Very Dark Place_. Both serve up a healthy dose of MAP/VO2 work, but the overall feeling of those two sessions is different.

If you find that your lower back starts to ache during this session or that you have to start rocking in the saddle to keep the power up, then it’s time for you to get started on the SYSTM Yoga program. Kick it off with “Core Strengtheners ” to make sure your core is just as strong as those legs.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[When to Train with Low Cadence](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/when-to-train-with-low-cadence)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: Balance & Mobility
prospects.description:
This balance sequence is excellent for training balance and proprioception, while also improving overall mobility, particularly in the spine and hips. It provides a challenging workout for the quads and glutes, making it a great choice for the morning or before a workout.

​

The objectives include improving balance, proprioception, and body awareness; strengthening the knees, quads, and glutes; opening up the hips and chest; enhancing mobility in the spine; boosting focus and concentration; and practicing diaphragmatic, nasal breathing.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- High Lunge with Chest Opener
- Flying Lunge
- Warrior 3 with Chest Opener
- Chair Pose Twists
- Revolved Side Angle
- Awkward Pose
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Aerobic Run 60
prospects.description:
This is an easy, fun, and unstructured run designed to keep your system ticking over without adding too much fatigue. Make it a priority to never go above Z2, and a good way to do this is to go for a run with a friend and keep it at a conversational pace (or talk to yourself!).

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-Up**

NA

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: NA

Interval Duration: 60 minutes

Interval Effort: RPE 2-4 -- 145-120% of RTP --HR 70-87% (Z2)

NA

prospects.name: Foot & Ankle Recovery
prospects.description:
In this restorative sequence, the focus is on mobilizing the toes, feet, and ankles, stretching the calves and hamstrings, and opening up the hips. The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Easy Seat
- Box Breathing
- Foot Massage
- Downward Dog
- Screaming Toe
- Yoga Squat
- Ankle Stretch
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: The Amazing Chase
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2021): Ultra-endurance cyclist Jack Thompson set out to ride the 2021 Tour de France route as fast as he could. 3,552km divided over 21 stages, his goal was to chase down the PRO peloton on his way to Paris. What would it take? What was realistic? What was possible? Follow Jack's journey as he battles the elements, the vagaries of the route, and intense mental and physical fatigue to arrive at the Champs-Élysées in Paris.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session, which is a very low-intensity ride. It's so easy that your power remains at or below 50% of FTP or an RPE less than 2.5, and your heart rate stays in zone 1 the entire time. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting (But not so interesting that you can't pay attention to the film).

prospects.name: 3 x (8 x 50m)
prospects.description:
For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

**Warm Up**

Number of Sets: 1

Number of Repeats: 6 x 100m @ RPE 3-4-- Z2, Focusing on distance per stroke

20 sec rest

​

**Activation**

Number of sets: 1

Number of Repeats: 4

Interval: 50m @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2 as 25m 2 strokes left, 2 strokes right drill + 25m swim

- Take 2 strokes with your left, then take 2 strokes with your right. Focus on initiating the strokes from the hips and following through to the shoulders, while pretending you are swimming over a barrel. Elbow should always be the highest point of the stroke during the catch and pull phase as well as the recovery phase. Recovery: 20 sec rest

**Main Set**

Number of Sets: 3

Interval 1: 8 x 50m @ RPE 7.5 -- Z4a, focusing on maintaining distance per stroke

Recovery: 20 sec rest

Interval 2: (Between each set of 50's) 100m backstroke or breaststroke RPE 2 -- Z1

​

**Cool Down**

200m @ RPE 2 -- Z1, choice of strokes

​

**Total Distance**

2300m

prospects.name: Recovery Run
prospects.description:
This is as easy as easy gets.

You should hardly be going fast enough to consider this a jog.

You want to focus on taking very short strides but keeping your stride rate at least 80 steps per minute.

You should be embarrassed to be seen going this slowly!

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-Up **NA

​

**Main Effort** 

Number of Sets 1 

Rest Between Sets: NA 

Interval Repeats Per Set NA 

Interval Effort: 20 minutes @ RPE 1-3 -- 165-140% of RTP -- HR <70% (Z1) 

Recovery: NA

​

**Extra Volume** NA

​

**Cool Down** NA

prospects.name: The Frozen Road
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2017): From the creator: "Self-shot and edited whilst cycling around the world, this film charts a winter journey into the Canadian Arctic as I completed my bike ride up the American continent. Compelled by Jack London’s assertion, that ‘any man who is a man can travel alone,' I sought an adventure of perfect solitude. Yet, as I came to realize, the harsh truths of traveling in such a formidable environment were a long way from the romantic images I’d held of this land. _The Frozen Road_’ is an honest reflection on my solo trip; of the wonder, terror and frustration I experienced when riding through the unforgiving emptiness of one of the world’s ‘last great wildernesses."

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Hip and Pelvis Stability
prospects.description: In this Intermediate sequence, we strengthen the hips through their full range of motion and stabilize the pelvis to improve balance and reduce your risk of knee, IT band, and lower back injury. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 3 Pt 3
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023):

**Episode 4: Finding Balance**

We follow Megan Mouser and her journey from 3 years of FTGU. Megan is an incredible mom, self described as "Workin' on body positivity 1 mile at a time and the epitome of our community at From the Ground Up. We are so excited to finally share her story up to race day!

​

**Episode 5: Rookies Again**

What does it take for ex-NFL athletes to redefine a healthy lifestyle and take on something as foreign as riding a mountain

bike? Kawika and Amani took a leap this year, and are working to inspire and motivate other athletes post career. In this episode we look at Kawika and Amani's backgrounds and watch them learn to ride a MTB comfortably as they step onto a whole new type of playing field.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.
